questions.question: That is not ………………… the color I wanted.
questions.description: Not quite can mean not exactly.

questions.question: You eat ……………… too much.
questions.description: Rather can modify comparatives and too.

questions.question: My mother would rather we …………….. to each other any more.
questions.description: After would rather, we use a past tense with a present or future meaning.

questions.question: I will go and see the Prime Minister himself if I have to.
questions.description: When words like himself, herself and themselves are used to mean ‘that person and nobody else’, it is used as an emphatic pronoun.
answers: Here himself is used as an emphatic pronoun.
Here himself is used as a reflexive pronoun.

questions.question: I will never forget the day ……………… my daughter was born.
This is Ms. Malini ………………. last year.
questions.description: The relative pronoun acts as the subject or object of the relative clause. It replaces words like he, him, her etc.

questions.question: ……………… money he has comes from his wife’s family.
questions.description: The sentence ‘What money he has…’ means the same as ‘The money that he has…’

questions.question: They saved hundreds of refugees, ………………… had been at sea for several days.
He turned the radio down ...................... he wouldn’t disturb the old lady downstairs.
questions.description: So that suggests a cause and effect relationship.

questions.question: A lot of social problems ……………. caused by unemployment.
questions.description: If the noun following ‘a lot of’ is plural, the verb is also plural.

questions.question: I will lend it to you on condition that you ……………… it back tomorrow.
questions.description: In subordinate clauses we often use the present tense to refer to the future

questions.question: It doesn’t matter what you .................... with your time or money.
questions.description: Present tenses are common after expressions like it doesn’t matter and I don’t care.
